subject: Coronavirus pandemic
title: What are the Covid rules in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland?
article: All remaining Covid-19 restrictions in Northern Ireland are no longer legally binding as of 17:00 GMT on 15 February. Some restrictions remain in place in other parts of the UK. Covid certificates in nightclubs, mandatory face coverings, track and trace requirements and the cap on 30 people in private homes are no longer legal requirements. Health Minister Robin Swann said legal measures would be replaced by guidance, such as recommending face masks are still worn in certain public settings. Current Covid restrictions are due to expire in England on 24 March. Boris Johnson has now told MPs thatthe remaining domestic rules would end a month early "provided the current encouraging trends in the data continue". This would removethe requirement for people to self-isolate if they haveCovid symptoms or test positive.He said that the government would outline its new strategy when parliament returns from recess on 21 February, and would expect to lift the rules later that week.The few measures left in England include: Guidance towork from home has ended, and care homes no longer haveany limit on visitor numbers . Remaining restrictions include: Anyone who had their second dose more than four months ago must also havereceived a booster to be considered fully vaccinated.Work from home advice has ended, although the government wants some staff to continue working remotely.
